Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Organic/Inorganic Hybrid Circuits on Film using Photolithography
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to demonstrate the integration of hybrid materials (both organic and inorganic) onto a flexible substrate using a photolithographic process made possible by the proprietary fluorinated resist chemistry of Orthogonal. First, the challenges of performing photolithography on flexible substrates will be addressed by using new resist materials, and investigating both a lamination process that would place the flexible materials onto a rigid substrate and a roll-to-roll process. At the same time, device parameters will be explored on rigid substrates in order to design and optimize high-performance circuits based on hybrid electronic structures. Finally, the optimized devices will be made on flexible substrates using the best methodology determined.

The broader/commercial impact of this project will be the potential to enable the large-scale manufacturing of organic flexible electronic devices by leveraging the existing infrastructure used in the display industry. The complementary circuits based on oxide as well as organic semiconductors will allow for high-performance and low-power circuit designs on plastic for Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) and sensor applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Phase I project established the viability of using the techniques used in making LCD TVs in order to make flexible circuits using a variety of materials, all integrated onto one platform. The Orthogonal photoresist system, originally developed at Cornell University and commercialized by Orthogonal, Inc., funded in part by SBIR Phase I grant 094570, had been demonstrated to allow the fabrication of organic electronic devices. Such devices had the potential to be made on plastic and integrated with other material systems to make flexible displays or logic circuits. Actually making devices on flexible substrates using traditional techniques had yet to be demonstrated. This was an important step because until this time, the only techniques being considered for the manufacturing of flexible circuits involved various forms of printing, which were new to the display industry and would require massive investments and a steep learning curve for manufacturers.

 

The project demonstrated that both organic electronic devices as well as inorganic (oxide) devices could be made together on a common flexible film platform. The devices were tested and the performance was found to be in line with devices made on rigid substrates, despite the additional processing needed to put both on the same film. The process that was created still had a high level of variation between devices and between films. This is something that will be addressed during later stages of commercialization, now that the process has been shown to be feasible.

 

The techniques developed during the project have helped Orthogonal support its large manufacturing customers during their trials with the product. One customer has successfully shown a demonstration of a flexible eReader using these processes. No customers have shown interest in integrating organic and inorganic semiconductors in precisely the same way as was demonstrated here, but the same concepts of integration still apply to organic electronic devices as they do to hybrid devices. Finally, the areas of improvement needed have been clearly identified, so work can now begin to bring Orthogonal’s processes into mass production with display manufacturers to make the next-generation eReaders.

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2012
Modified by: John Defranco
